citation.article-title: Methanobacterium congolense sp. nov., from a methanogenic fermentation of cassava peel
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Methanobacterium congolense sp. nov.
Methanobacterium congolense (con.go.len'se. N.L. adj. congolense from the Congo, where the type strain was isolated)
Colonies are circular, white, opaque, raised at the centres, have rough surfaces and entire margins and are up to 1 mm in diameter.
The cells are rods, 0.4-0.5x2-10 μm, occurring individually or in pairs, rarely in chains and small aggregates.
Obligatory member of the Euryarchaeota of the domain Archaea.
H2/CO2 is the only substrate that supports growth.
Methane is produced from 2-propanol/CO2, 2-butanol/CO2 and cyclopentanol/CO2 without growth.
Formate, acetate, methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol, isobutanol, 1-butanol, pentanol, methylamine and trimethylamine are not used.
Growth factors such as yeast extract, bio-Trypcase and vitamins are not required.
The optimum growth temperature is between 37 and 42 °C.
The optimum pH is 7.2; no growth occurs at pH 5.9 or 8.2.
The doubling time under optimal growth conditions is 7.5 h.
The DNA base composition is 39.5±0.3 mol% G+C (as determined by HPLC).
Isolated from an anaerobic digester used for the treatment of cassava peel in the Congo (Central Africa).
